name: Barbara Liskov
background: Turing Award winner, MIT professor. Created CLU language, developed Liskov Substitution Principle (the L in SOLID). Pioneer of data abstraction and object-oriented programming foundations.

principles.name: Liskov Substitution Principle
principles.description: Subtypes must be substitutable for their base types without altering program correctness. If S is a subtype of T, objects of type T may be replaced with objects of type S without breaking behavior.
principles.falsification: When strict LSP compliance creates excessive complexity or when duck typing in dynamic languages makes formal substitutability impractical

principles.name: Data abstraction hides implementation
principles.description: Separate what something does from how it does it. Users depend on interface contracts, not internal details. This enables independent evolution of implementations.
principles.falsification: When abstraction layers add latency/complexity without value, or when leaky abstractions are unavoidable (networked systems, performance-critical code)

principles.name: Design for change
principles.description: Anticipate that requirements will evolve. Structure code so changes are localized. The cost of change should be proportional to the scope of change.
principles.falsification: When over-engineering for hypothetical changes delays shipping, or when the system is truly throwaway
